Title:
Phylogenetic position and genetic diversity of Cercospora
seminalis causing false smut in buffalograss.
Keywords:
AFLP, Buchloe dactyloides, Cercospora seminalis, false
smut, genetic diversity, ITS, phylogenetics
Abstract:
False smut caused by Cercospora seminalis is an important
disease of buffalograss seed production. The pathogen prevents seed
development and causes considerable loss of yield and reduced
germination of buffalograss seed. Taxonomic placement of false smut
under Cercospora genus is uncertain since no known sexual stage has been
identified for the pathogen. Furthermore, no genetic diversity studies
have been reported on this pathogen. The objectives of this study were
to determine phylogenetic position of false smut within the Cercospora
genus and to obtain information on genetic diversity of fungal isolates
from distinct buffalograss seed production fields. Phylogenetic analysis
based on internal transcribed spacer (ITS) sequences revealed a
monophyletic group for the false smut isolates, forming a distinct clade
from Cercospora and other related genera. A collection of 86 C.
seminalis isolates were made from six buffalograss sites in Nebraska.
DNA fingerprinting analysis was performed by amplified fragment length
polymorphism (AFLP) using four selective primer combinations. In total,
481 DNA markers were scored across all isolates. All of the markers were
polymorphic for the isolates. The dendrogram constructed by the
unweighted pair‚Äêgrouped method with arithmetic average (UPGMA) clustered
more than 50% of the isolates into two clades. The remaining isolates
formed several small groups or stood alone. An analysis of molecular
variance (AMOVA) test showed that the two main clades are significantly
different at P =0.001. However the many small clusters and stand alone
isolates indicate high heterogeneity of the fungus. No relationship was
observed between the isolate geographic origins and the UPGMA clusters.
Further characterization of the pathogen is needed to understand its
proper taxonomic position. A diversity study with larger number of
isolates from distant geographies is necessary to make inferences on the
population structure of false smut.
